title: A Culture of Honesty - The University of Georgia's Academic Honesty Policy
summary: Comprehensive policy defining academic honesty requirements, prohibited conduct, and procedures for resolving alleged violations
honor_code: I will be academically honest in all of my academic work and will not tolerate academic dishonesty of others.
definition: Academic honesty is defined as completing all academic work without cheating, lying, stealing, or receiving assistance from any other person or using any source of information not appropriately authorized or attributed.

responsibilities: Report alleged violations to the Office of Academic Honesty
Participate in discussions with students believed to have violated the policy
Truthfully answer questions from Academic Honesty Panel
Report alleged violations within 15 days of discovery
Take reasonable steps to inform students of academic honesty expectations
Foster a climate of academic honesty
Use exclusive procedure outlined in this policy
Know and follow the policy (lack of knowledge is not an acceptable defense)
Avoid assisting other students without authorization

prohibited_conduct.general_rule: No student may complete, attempt, or help another engage in academic dishonesty on academic work. Any dishonest act can be a violation, whether intended or not.

categories.description: Using another's work as your own without correct citations
examples: Directly quoting without quotation marks
Paraphrasing without attribution
Presenting someone else's idea/theory as your own without attribution
Using statistics, images, or data without recognizing who compiled them
Turning in work that another wrote as your own
Self-Plagiarism: Submitting an assignment already submitted for credit unless authorized

categories.description: Giving or receiving help for assignments without prior approval
categories.default_rule: Any help (books, notes, calculators, technology, internet resources, conversations) is considered unauthorized unless the instructor explicitly allows it
examples: Copying or allowing others to copy answers
Sending/receiving/posting exam information before, during, or after the exam
Completing someone else's assignment or allowing them to complete yours
Collaborating on individual assignments
Submitting group work that doesn't represent all members' work
Using electronic devices without permission during exams

categories.description: Giving false information related to academic work
examples: Giving false reasons for failing to complete assignments
Falsifying laboratory/experimental work or data results
Altering work after submission and requesting credit
Altering grade, lab, or attendance records
Signing in for another student or providing attendance verification for absent students
Damaging equipment to prevent evaluation
Using someone else's password without permission
Impersonating another person
Giving false information in academic honesty proceedings

categories.description: Stealing information related to academic work
examples: Past exams
Grade records
Grading forms
Books, papers
Computer equipment and data
Laboratory equipment and data

action_prior_to_finding.course_withdrawal: Requests not approved until determination is made. If violation found, requires instructor permission.
action_prior_to_finding.instructor_obligations: Must let student complete all required assignments and grade all other work except assignments involved in alleged dishonesty
action_prior_to_finding.student_obligations: Should continue attending class and turning in all other assignments
action_prior_to_finding.discussion_restrictions: Student and instructor should not discuss alleged violation without a facilitator present

facilitated_discussion.purpose: Educational, fair, and focused discussion of what may have occurred
outcomes: Agreement that violation occurred with agreed-upon consequences
No agreement - proceeds to Continued Discussion

consequences_if_violation_acknowledged.eligibility_for_remediation: Enrolled undergraduates with no prior violations who acknowledge violation in Facilitated Discussion
consequences_if_violation_acknowledged.withdrawal_rights: May lose right to withdraw from course at instructor's discretion
consequences_if_violation_acknowledged.right_to_rescind: Student can withdraw from agreement within 5 days

continued_discussion.participants: Academic Honesty Panel (3 students, 2 faculty), instructor(s), student(s), Facilitator
continued_discussion.panel_composition_special_cases: Cases involving graduate/pharmacy/veterinary students must have at least 2 student panelists and 1 faculty panelist from associated college
continued_discussion.advisor_allowed: One advisor per party, cannot address Panel
continued_discussion.standard_of_proof: More likely than not (preponderance of evidence)
continued_discussion.notice_delivery: Deemed delivered 5 days after date of notice
continued_discussion.failure_to_attend: Panel may proceed in absence of student or instructor
minimum_consequences_if_violation_found: Lowest possible grade for assignment based on course grading scale
Plus at least one of: Final course grade of F, Transcript notation, Suspension, Dismissal, or Expulsion
continued_discussion.transcript_notation: Reads 'Academic Honesty Violation as Determined by the Office of the Vice President for Instruction.' Remains until student no longer enrolled and 2 years after Panel decision. Can petition for removal if no new violations.

multiple_violations_review_board.trigger: Student violates policy more than once
multiple_violations_review_board.composition: 2 faculty members, 1 student from certified panelist pool
multiple_violations_review_board.purpose: Assign additional consequences for multiple violations
minimum_consequences_second_violation: Plus one of: Expulsion, Dismissal, or Suspension

appeals.appeal_to: President of the university or designee
appeals.timeline: Within 5 days of delivery of decision
grounds: Instructor did not demonstrate 'more likely than not' that violation occurred
Student was denied a right in the process that affected the decision
New evidence found since Continued Discussion or MVRB meeting

key_definitions.dismissal: Cannot enroll for minimum of 3 consecutive semesters after term of violation. Readmission not automatic - must appeal to Petitions Subcommittee.
key_definitions.expulsion: Permanent severance from University. If issued after graduation for pre-graduation misconduct, results in recommendation to revoke degree.
key_definitions.suspension: Defined term of at least one semester where student cannot enroll. May return when suspension ends if enrollment requirements met.
key_definitions.subsequent_violation: Any additional violation after being found in violation by Facilitated Discussion or Continued Discussion
key_definitions.remediation_program: Available only to enrolled undergraduates with no prior violations who acknowledge violation in Facilitated Discussion. Completion results in record non-disclosure except in case of subsequent violation.

special_provisions.law_school: University of Georgia School of Law has separate policy. Law student violations of law school academic work are not subject to this policy.
special_provisions.relationship_to_non_academic_misconduct: Academic honesty policy takes precedence if same act violates both policies
special_provisions.criminal_proceedings: May proceed simultaneously with, before, or after civil/criminal proceedings
special_provisions.mandatory_annual_report: Office of Academic Honesty submits written report to University Council each fall term

records.privacy: Not open to public. Available to others only with written student request or per FERPA policy
records.retention: Per Board of Regents Records Retention Policy
